content.html: Can you add a text file to the media/materials/textures folder identifying the source of these new textures? (ie. which website they came from)

content.html: 112d35f added acknowledgement file

content.raw:
I think this is related to issue #1064 and sdformat issue #[45](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issue/45/allow-to-have-custom-textures) right,  have we decided that we'll be using the `<texture>` for this?  

Maybe we can consider using the `<material>` tag like we have for visuals. This then eliminates the need to check all possible texture strings in `gazebo/rendering/Road2d.cc`, and replace the checks with `this->setMaterial(materialName);` where `materialName` can be extracted from the proto msg
content.html:
I think this is related to issue #1064 and sdformat issue #45 right, have we decided that we'll be using the <texture> for this?

Maybe we can consider using the <material> tag like we have for visuals. This then eliminates the need to check all possible texture strings in gazebo/rendering/Road2d.cc, and replace the checks with this->setMaterial(materialName); where materialName can be extracted from the proto msg

content.raw: 112d35f added material tag.
content.html: 112d35f added material tag.

content.html: Steve, I'll do add the acknowledgement text file. Ian, that sounds like a good idea. If everyone agrees, I can start working on putting that bit together.

content.html: #include <string> (used in line 40)

content.raw: Its included in Road.hh. Should I remove it and put it in Road.cc?
content.html: Its included in Road.hh. Should I remove it and put it in Road.cc?

content.raw: You should make sure each file (header of source) includes everything it needs, and nothing more. So, in this case, the #include will appear in the header and implementation (but the #ifdef guards in the header file will prevent to include the code twice.). This is the rule that we're trying to follow in Gazebo.
content.html: You should make sure each file (header of source) includes everything it needs, and nothing more. So, in this case, the #include will appear in the header and implementation (but the #ifdef guards in the header file will prevent to include the code twice.). This is the rule that we're trying to follow in Gazebo.

content.raw: Got it!
content.html: Got it!

content.raw: The texture field is optional, you should check if the message has the texture field before reading it.
content.html: The texture field is optional, you should check if the message has the texture field before reading it.

content.raw: In case of unknow texture, should the default road texture still be displayed?
content.html: In case of unknow texture, should the default road texture still be displayed?

content.raw:
Yes, it's a good idea to show the road with a default texture but I would write a line in the log file (using gzerr) to capture that something didn't go smooth.

And before checking if the texture is valid or not, we should check if this road message contains a texture field because is an optional field. If it doesn't contain a texture field, or it does contain it but it's not valid we should render the road. The difference will be a warning line in the log.
content.html:
Yes, it's a good idea to show the road with a default texture but I would write a line in the log file (using gzerr) to capture that something didn't go smooth.

And before checking if the texture is valid or not, we should check if this road message contains a texture field because is an optional field. If it doesn't contain a texture field, or it does contain it but it's not valid we should render the road. The difference will be a warning line in the log.

content.raw: Ok. I corrected that. just wanted to make sure before commiting.
content.html: Ok. I corrected that. just wanted to make sure before commiting.

content.raw: I'd consider to use gzerr here to log that an unknown texture value has been received.
content.html: I'd consider to use gzerr here to log that an unknown texture value has been received.
